previous.name: The Brahmin Who Provided for His Mother

segments.pli: Atha kho bhikkhako brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
segments.en: Then a begging brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

segments.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho bhikkhako brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,

segments.pli: “ahampi kho, bho gotama, bhikkhako, bhavampi bhikkhako, idha no kiṃ nānākaraṇan”ti?
segments.en: “Master Gotama, both you and I are beggars. What, then, is the difference between us?”
Someone who has accepted domestic responsibilities
has not yet become a mendicant.
But one living a spiritual life
who has shunned both good and bad,
having considered, they live in this world:

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhako brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When he had spoken, the begging brahmin said to the Buddha,

segments.pli: “abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama … pe …
upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
segments.en: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

suttaplex.blurb: The Buddha explains that a true mendicant is one who has gone beyond evil.
